title: South Africa reveal scope of random drug testing at Rugby World Cup
text:
South Africa’s forwards coach, Matt Proudfoot, has revealed almost every player can expect to be drug tested at the World Cup as he was questioned over his nation’s record on anti-doping.

Rugby World Cup has stepped up its anti-doping programme such that two players from each team will be tested after every match and all 20 sides will be randomly visited every week by anti-doping officials from Japan.

Rugby World Cup 2019: South Africa team guide Read more

The organisers refused to say at a media conference this week how many players would provide samples in random visits, which occur at any hour of the day or night, but Proudfoot was more illuminating.

“Between six and eight players are tested every week [out of competition],” said Proudfoot, whose side has been in Japan for a fortnight having arranged to play the hosts in a warm-up. “Testing is a viable mechanism to ensure a clean sport and doping continually needs to be addressed on a worldwide basis, and not just in rugby.”

The South Africa wing Aphiwe Dyantyi, World Rugby’s breakthrough player of the year in 2018, is not at the World Cup after testing positive for three steroids, a result upheld by a B-sample. He is contesting the findings but last year, at a showcase tournament for aspiring professionals, six boys failed tests and were banned.

When asked if South African rugby had a doping issue, especially at junior level, Proudfoot said: “It is not my role to answer that question and I would not have the information.” But he insisted: “The image of South African rugby is what you see on the field. We are a competitive nation and that shows in every team.”

Mike Earl, World Rugby’s anti-doping manager, said the average fail rate at elite level since the last World Cup was 0.4%. “In the last year, all the teams in the tournament have been visited in and out of competition by us and by other organisations.

“It is when we consider there to be the highest risk of doping, although that does not mean there could not be a case during the tournament. We do not think there is a significant problem but we are not complacent. The testing will reflect that. It will involve two players from each team after every match and there will be visits to teams in between games, although we cannot say how regular they will be.”

Proudfoot preferred to talk about the match on Saturday against New Zealand in Yokohama, a meeting between the sides who between them have won the past three tournaments and a potential rehearsal for the final.

“The forecast is rain, but the conditions will be the same for both sides,” he said. “We have been here for two weeks and have had the full spectrum of weather. Our mindset this year has been to generate a lot of momentum, and it would be good to keep it going.

“It is not ideal to start a competition on the back foot and both teams understand that. The nature of the contest between the two teams has been so close for the last 18 months. It is all about the result rather than what the rest of the tournament will look like win or lose and I expect another tight game between two rivals that will be won and lost on small executions. I do not think the loser will be derailed. It does not make a difference who you play in the quarter-finals because so many teams are well prepared and can beat each other.

Proudfoot said he would not be surprised if New Zealand started with the second-row Brodie Retallick, who was all but ruled out of the first three group matches through injury. “They will have a little trick up their sleeve. We enjoy playing against the All Blacks and we understand each other. It is two different styles and I am sure they will bring something different to the game in their attack, a new arrow in their quiver. They are too good a side not to keep evolving.”
